guide.introduction: If you want to make music, then this project is for you. This is a theremin-like device to control the pitch and volume of a musical note. It utilizes a photo-resistor to control the pitch, and an ultrasonic sensor to control a servo which turns a potentiometer controlling the volume.
guide.introduction_rendered:
If you want to make music, then this project is for you. This is a theremin-like device to control the pitch and volume of a musical note. It utilizes a photo-resistor to control the pitch, and an ultrasonic sensor to control a servo which turns a potentiometer controlling the volume.

Relevant parts
  • Arduino microcontroller, Uno or Duemilanove
  • Breadboard kit
  • 3-16V Piezo Buzzer (RadioShack #273-074)
  • VEX Ultrasonic Range Finder
  • CdS Photoresistor
  • 10K Resistor
  • Potentiometer, 5kΩ, audio taper
  • Servo (generic)
  • Circuit board header: 3-pin
  • Breadboard jumper wires, or solid core 22AWG wire
  • Wire
  • Rubber bands
  • Dowel, 3/8" dia. 1/2" length
  • Sandpaper
Tools
  • Hot Glue gun & hot glue
  • Soldering iron
  • Super glue

parts.text: Breadboard jumper wires, or solid core 22AWG wire

lines.text: Solder wires onto the potentiometer. I used red for the audio voltage in on the left and green for the voltage out in the center.
lines.text_raw: Solder wires onto the potentiometer. I used red for the audio voltage in on the left and green for the voltage out in the center.

lines.text: I initially soldered on a black wire on the third pin, but removed it as it was redundant.
lines.text_raw: I initially soldered on a black wire on the third pin, but removed it as it was redundant.

lines.text: Hot glue the dowel onto the servo, centered, and then super glue the sandpaper to the dowel to provide traction for the rubber band.
lines.text_raw: Hot glue the dowel onto the servo, centered, and then super glue the sandpaper to the dowel to provide traction for the rubber band.

lines.text: Find a rubber band, preferably wide, that can be used to transfer the servo motion to the potentiometer.
lines.text_raw: Find a rubber band, preferably wide, that can be used to transfer the servo motion to the potentiometer.

lines.text: Hot glue the potentiometer in place. Don't be sparing with the hot glue, as it is not terribly strong.
lines.text_raw: Hot glue the potentiometer in place. Don't be sparing with the hot glue, as it is not terribly strong.

lines.text: Turn both the potentiometer and servo all the way to the left and link them together with the rubber band. I had to use several as the servo shifted while the glue was cooling.
lines.text_raw: Turn both the potentiometer and servo all the way to the left and link them together with the rubber band. I had to use several as the servo shifted while the glue was cooling.

lines.text: Supply +5V to the power rail on the breadboard, and then to the power pin on each ultrasonic sensor, the servo power pin, and the photo-resistor.
lines.text_raw: Supply +5V to the power rail on the breadboard, and then to the power pin on each ultrasonic sensor, the servo power pin, and the photo-resistor.

lines.text: Supply GND to the GND rail on the breadboard, and then to the ground pin on each ultrasonic sensor, the servo ground pin, and the piezo buzzer ground pin.
lines.text_raw: Supply GND to the GND rail on the breadboard, and then to the ground pin on each ultrasonic sensor, the servo ground pin, and the piezo buzzer ground pin.

lines.text: I used analog 0 for the photo-resistor output, digital 10 for the servo, digital 2 for the ultrasonic output, and digital 8 for the ultrasonic input
lines.text_raw: I used analog 0 for the photo-resistor output, digital 10 for the servo, digital 2 for the ultrasonic output, and digital 8 for the ultrasonic input

lines.text: Use a 10kΩ resistor as a pull-down for the photo-resistor by connecting it to GND and analog 0, or whatever analog pin you end up connecting the photo-resistor to.
lines.text_raw: Use a 10kΩ resistor as a pull-down for the photo-resistor by connecting it to GND and analog 0, or whatever analog pin you end up connecting the photo-resistor to.

lines.text: See attached file, <tt>theremin.pdf</tt>, for the code.
lines.text_raw: See attached file, ``theremin.pdf``, for the code.

lines.text: The volume should increase as your hand is moved closer to the ultrasonic sensor, so if the opposite happens, simply reverse the mapping of the servo position.
lines.text_raw: The volume should increase as your hand is moved closer to the ultrasonic sensor, so if the opposite happens, simply reverse the mapping of the servo position.

lines.text: To do this, change the code from <tt>rad = map(dist, 8, 20, 0, 90);</tt> to <tt>rad = map(dist, 8, 20, 90, 0);</tt>
lines.text_raw: To do this, change the code from ``rad = map(dist, 8, 20, 0, 90);`` to ``rad = map(dist, 8, 20, 90, 0);``
